Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: River Electrical Energy Devices
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project proposes the development of river energy harvesters uniquely suited to harvesting energy from undammed turbulent river flows, currently untapped due to state-of-the-art technology limitations. Mature renewable energy technologies include silicon based solar panels, large scale wind turbines, and high-head hydropower turbines. However, consumers are often geographically distant from these resources. The vast majority of people live adjacent to life-sustaining waterways. Millions live in remote parts of the world alongside vast hydrokinetic resources, but currently have little or no access to reliable electricity. This program specifically seeks to address such underserved markets. Recently, there has been growing interest in harvesting from flows with significant kinetic energy, which have been described in a US resource assessment study as a "gargantuan" untapped natural resource. But with existing technology, siting continues to be the single biggest challenge facing expansion of this high-energy renewable resource. This project aims to develop harvesters specifically suited to turbulent and/or very low head flows, thereby expanding hydro-energy siting options and potentially enabling a second hydro-power boom.

The Phase II technical effort will explore the conversion of hydrokinetic energy to mechanical energy via a dynamic, fluid-solid interaction. An example of the phenomenon to be harnessed is the bouncing motion observed in power lines on rainy, windy days. The repeating motion is observed only during specific weather conditions because the unstable dynamics are a function of both the flow type, and the geometry of the affected surface. This motion is undesirable in most instances, including for power lines, but it also represents an energy conversion opportunity from ill-behaved flows. The Phase I project identified and demonstrated two specific adaptive structures strategies for enhancing the desired energy conversion; additional strategies were identified and will be investigated during a Phase II project. The goal of this Phase II program is to demonstrate technical and commercial feasibility of the resulting technology by building and operating a 2 kilowatt prototype in the field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes

Overview:

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project developed a prototype power generator uniquely suited to harvesting energy from undammed turbulent river flows, currently untapped due to state-of-the-art technology limitations. Renergé’s vision is to enable an expansion of hydropower harvest, with cascading economic benefits, through tapping a gargantuan resource co-located with consumers. In Phase II, Renergé explored several technological concepts relating to the development of the harvester and demonstrated the practical and commercial potential of this design while addressing the needs of remote power users.

Intellectual Merit:

This Small Business Innovation Research Project explored the conversion of hydrokinetic energy to electrical and mechanical energy via a dynamic, fluid-solid interaction. An example is the bouncing motion observed in power lines on rainy, windy days. The unstable dynamics are a function of both the flow type, and the geometry of the affected surface. This motion is undesirable in most instances, including for power lines, but it also represents an energy conversion opportunity from ill-behaved flows. This Phase II program explored several cost-effective suspension and power transmission mechanisms that maintained the desired system dynamics resulting in multiple patent applications and enabled the transition to less expensive off-the-shelf components where custom hardware developed in-house was used in Phase I. Additionally, significant design changes were made to the harvester in reaction to the expressed needs of potential end user discovered in the course of this project which solved some technology challenges while introducing new ones. Multiple full-scale prototypes were demonstrated in river environments revealing that the power conversion methods developed using bench-scale prototypes did scale to sizes required for a commercially viable product.

Additionally, REU and RAHSS programs were conducted to promote STEM education while exploring the impact of the harvester on river turbidity and the impact of river debris on the harvester.

Broader Impacts:

Mature renewable energy technologies include silicon based solar panels, large scale wind turbines, and high-head hydropower turbines. But inspection of the respective resource maps alongside that of a population density map reveals that in general, consumers are geographically distant from these resources. The vast majority of people live adjacent to life-sustaining waterways, both in the US where hydropower continues to dominate the US renewable energy portfolio despite the fact that the hydro-power boom ended decades ago, and in remote parts of the world, such as in the Amazon Basin, where millions of people live alongside vast hydrokinetic resources, but currently have little or no access to reliable electricity. Recently, there has been growing interest in harvesting from flows with significant kinetic energy, which has been described in a US resource assessment study as a "gargantuan" untapped natural resource. But per the current state of the art, siting continues to be the single biggest challenge facing expansion of this high energy density renewable resource. In contrast, the technology developed in this Phase II project is specifically suited to turbulent and/or very low head flows, dramatically expanding hydro-energy siting options.
